titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Tanzania
Tanzania

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Christopher Morrison, March 2008

div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States established diplomatic relations with Tanzania in 1961. Relations between the two countries, which had been cordial since Tanzania (then Tanganyika) won its independence from Great Britain, improved further following terrorists attacks against the U.S. embassies in Dar es Salaam and Nairobi on August 7, 1998.

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Tanganyika’s Independence, 1961.
div.p: The United States recognized Tanganyika on December 9, 1961, in a congratulatory message from President John F. Kennedy to Prime Minister Julius Nyerere. Tanganyika previously had been under British administration as a United Nations Trust Territory

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations and the American Embassy in Tanganyika, 1961.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on December 9, 1961, when the American consulate general at Dar es Salaam was raised to Embassy status with William R. Duggan as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.
